title: Gareth Bale and Jermain Defoe swear by Cryotherapy - so what it's like in the freezing 'Ice Box?'
text:
Get football   Thank you for subscribing!   
Performing at the top level is all about staying cool under pressure. But more than ever that applies off the pitch, as well as on it. 
Science in football is changing at a fast pace. The days of jumping in an ice bath or a wheelie bin full of freezing cold water post-match are becoming a thing of the past. 
More and more clubs are introducing cryotherapy instead, with players exposed to temperatures as low as -150C for a few minutes to shock the body and help aid their recovery. 
The treatment also allows players to train with greater intensity, reduce muscle soreness, aid sleep and provide an exhilarating post-chamber sensation. Read More Jermain Defoe credits cryotherapy for keeping him in top shape (Photo: Instagram/iamjermaindefoe) Gareth Bale looks ice cool in a cryo unit (Photo: Twitter/@GarethBale11) 
Cristiano Ronaldo is renowned for his incredible fitness levels and reportedly once installed a chamber in his own house to keep him in top shape. 
His Real Madrid teammate, Gareth Bale , is no stranger to the ‘ice box’, while Leicester’s stars used cryotherapy regularly last season on their way to the Premier League title. 
Jamie Vardy said: “The cryo chamber that we’ve got at the training ground’s come in useful. It’s absolutely freezing but it helps you in your recovery so fair play to the club for getting that in." Leicester were big fans of the cryotherapy unit Foxes skipper Wes Morgan exits the chamber 
However, Fulham have taken things up a notch. 
The Championship outfit have become the world's first elite sports club to introduce tailored full-body cryotherapy, teaming up with PolarFit Care, Air Products and ProCcare to give Slavisa Jokanovic’s men the best possible chance of success in their promotion push. 
The likes of Tom Cairney , Chris Martin and Scott Parker all have personalised programs to help them achieve peak performance. 
There has been a 94 per cent compliance among the first-team squad, with their academy starlets also buying into the new sports science unit which would set you back around £120,000 to purchase. Read More Mirror man Jacob Murtagh prepares to brave the cryotherapy chamber (Photo: DAILY MIRROR) The chamber plummeted to -130C (Photo: DAILY MIRROR) 
Jokanovic is reaping the rewards of having more of his playing squad available this term compared to last time out. 
But what could cryotherapy do for a thirty-something Sunday League journeyman? 
I went along to their headquarters in south-west London to give the state-of-the-art facilities a try. 
Now a cold shower after football on an icy Sunday morning is bad enough, so the idea of exposing my body to sub-zero temperatures in nothing more than a pair of shorts, socks and safety gear almost saw me cry off at the 11th hour. 
After providing the PolarFit team with my vital statistics (70kg), I was told I would spend two-and-a-half minutes in the cryo chamber (lighter players can endure the cold for longer). Murtagh dons the safety gear (Photo: DAILY MIRROR) 
First up was the pre-chamber of around -60C to ease me into it. If that was a shock to the system, nothing could prepare me for what lay ahead. 
I was plunged in at -130C. I was encouraged to keep on my toes to make the 150 seconds bearable. 
It got worse as the clock ticked down, with my fingers, ankles and knees especially frozen to the core. 
I was relieved once the session was over, but once I had the chance to warm up, I started to feel the benefits. The Sunday League journeyman covers up (Photo: DAILY MIRROR) Murtagh attempts to warm up after the big freeze from the PolarFit unit (Photo: DAILY MIRROR) 
I felt uplifted and fingers crossed it will help aid my recovery from the bumps and bruises I’ve picked up during my way around the Sunday League circuit. It certainly helped me get a better night's sleep. 
It’s certainly no wonder Cairney and Scott Malone are at the front of the queue at Motspur Park. 
Fulham captain Cairney said: “I feel like the cryotherapy sessions do help me because I’ve played a lot of matches and a lot of minutes this season. It hits you deeper than an ice bath.” 
Malone added: “It helps with performance and it definitely makes us feel fresher. I certainly feel better for it in-game, so it’s obviously working.” Tom Cairney has been in stunning form for Fulham this season (Photo: Getty Images Europe) 
Fulham first-team physio Chris Hanson said: “We tailor most aspects of the players’ schedules, from training to therapy and even diet, based on things like body type, age and position in the team. 
“Any treatment that can be intelligently applied based on the needs of an individual player is bound to increase its effectiveness. A more tailored approach will improve the positive results of cryotherapy.” 
Fulham have been frozen out of the Premier League for three seasons, but Jokanovic will be hoping this can help give them the edge over their promotion rivals in the latter stages of the campaign. poll loading Will Fulham make the play-offs? 0+ VOTES SO FAR
